title: How to prove that (p∧q) ∨ r is logically equivalent to (p ∨ r) ∧ (q∨r) - Quora

response.answer_text: In every logical system there must be unproved premises, that are assumed to apply to the universe of instances that satisfy the premises. Often both distributive laws are taken as premises without proof. But by interpreting the equivalence in terms of subsets, we can easily show that each element in one of the two subsets is also in the other, thus showing they are equivalent. Remember. Boolean algebra is just subset algebra.

How do you prove that (p∧q) ∨ r is logically equivalent to (p ∨ r) ∧ (q∨r)? Refer to my answer when you asked the question without using LaTeX typography. There’s no need to make a new question, just edit the old. See: Terry Moore's answer to In math logic, how is (p v q)->r equivalent to (p->r) and (q->r)?
Whenever you want to prove that two statements in propositional logic are equivalent, a truth table will do the trick.
